itemsOfInterest.name: Historic Carousel & Museum
itemsOfInterest.description: Since the early 2000s, this hand-carved carousel has been built, starting with a restored classic 1909 Dentzel Carousel Corporation mechanism. It currently features 41 animals with 52 total planned. The carousel is fun for the whole family, but not the only thing on display. There's also a carousel museum, party rooms, and a gift shop, which sells personally-signed copies of 'Caesar the No drama Llama' (yes, that stamp is a scaled copy of his hoofprint).

itemsOfInterest.name: Talking Water Gardens
itemsOfInterest.description: Used as a water treatment wetland since 2010, Talking Water Gardens mimics the cleansing and cooling processes that occur in nature to return treated waste water to the environment. In addition to cooling and aerating the water so it's safe to return to the Willamette, Talking Water Gardens features walking trails, waterfalls, wetland plants, and over 100 species of birds and waterfowl.

itemsOfInterest.name: Albany Regional Museum
itemsOfInterest.address: 136 SE Lyon St S, Albany, OR 97231
itemsOfInterest.description: Renovated in 2023, the Albany Regional Museum showcases both permanent and rotating exhibits including thousands or artifacts and photographs. Diaramas portray historical businesses and the people that have worked in the various industries that have supported Albany in its 170-plus year history.

itemsOfInterest.name: Monteith House
itemsOfInterest.description: The Monteith House is the restored home of Albany founders Walter and Thomas Monteith. Completed in 1849, it not only served as the Monteith family home, but as a meeting place for religious, political, and other activities. The home is now operated by volunteers who offer tours and special events, including pioneer and ghost story-telling, music, and interactive pioneer activies like woodworking, doll making, baking biscuits, and making butter.

itemsOfInterest.name: Albany Civic Theater
itemsOfInterest.description: One of the oldest, best-known community theaters in Oregon, the Albany Civic Theater is an all-volunteer, non-profit community theater. With a year-round season, ACT brings top-quality comedies, dramas, and musicals to a wide range of audience tastes. Albany Civic theater strives to 'enrich our audiences through a variety of productions that enhance the cultural life of our community.'

itemsOfInterest.name: Grand Prairie Park
itemsOfInterest.address: 2530 Grand Prairie Rd SE, Albany, Oregon 97322
itemsOfInterest.description: This small park with picnic tables and basketball courts attracts a few Eurasian Wigeon along with American Wigeon flocks in most winters, as well as scaup and gull flocks that regularly include Glaucous-winged, Herring, Thayer's, and California Gulls, with chance of Western or Glaucous Gulls

itemsOfInterest.name: Monteith Riverpark
itemsOfInterest.description: Monteith Park is the starting point of a path that runs along the river. It also has a stage where free concerts are held during the summer.

itemsOfInterest.name: Historic Albany Downtown
itemsOfInterest.description: Historic Downtown Albany is a vibrant area filled with architectural and historical charm, showcasing a mix of architectural styles from the late 1800s and early 1900s. It's a designated National Register Historic District, offering a unique blend of historic buildings, antique shops, boutiques, art galleries, restaurants, and museums.
